challenges.name: üîí Security Group Configuration
challenges.description: A security audit revealed an improperly configured security group!
challenges.question: What is the BEST practice for configuring AWS Security Groups?
options: Allow all inbound traffic (0.0.0.0/0) for convenience
Use the principle of least privilege - only allow necessary ports
Only configure outbound rules, ignore inbound
Disable security groups to improve performance
challenges.explanation: Security groups should follow the principle of least privilege - only allow the minimum necessary access. Opening all ports (0.0.0.0/0) creates security vulnerabilities.

challenges.name: üîê IAM Best Practices
challenges.description: Your IAM policies need review for security compliance!
challenges.question: Which IAM best practice is MOST important for production environments?
options: Share root account credentials with the team
Use access keys for all authentication
Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for privileged users
Grant administrator access to all developers
challenges.explanation: MFA adds an extra layer of security and is critical for privileged accounts. Root credentials should never be shared, and admin access should be limited.

challenges.name: üîì S3 Bucket Permissions
challenges.description: An S3 bucket has potential security issues!
challenges.question: How should you secure sensitive data in S3?
options: Make all buckets public for easy access
Use bucket policies, ACLs, enable encryption at rest and in transit
Rely only on obscure bucket names
Disable all access controls
challenges.explanation: S3 security requires multiple layers: bucket policies for access control, encryption at rest (SSE), encryption in transit (SSL/TLS), and proper ACL configuration.

challenges.name: ‚ö° Database Performance
challenges.description: Your RDS database is experiencing high latency!
challenges.question: What is the BEST way to improve RDS read performance?
options: Increase the instance size indefinitely
Implement Read Replicas for read-heavy workloads
Disable all indexes to speed up queries
Store everything in a single large table
challenges.explanation: Read Replicas allow you to scale read operations horizontally by distributing queries across multiple database instances, significantly improving performance for read-heavy applications.

challenges.name: üöÄ CDN Implementation
challenges.description: Users are experiencing slow content delivery globally!
challenges.question: What is the primary benefit of using CloudFront CDN?
options: It makes your code run faster
It caches content at edge locations closer to users
It increases your server's CPU power
It replaces the need for S3
challenges.explanation: CloudFront is a Content Delivery Network (CDN) that caches content at edge locations worldwide, reducing latency by serving content from locations closer to users.

challenges.name: ‚öôÔ∏è Auto Scaling Strategy
challenges.question: When should you use Auto Scaling for EC2 instances?
options: Never, manual scaling is always better
Only during business hours
When traffic patterns are variable and unpredictable
Only for development environments
challenges.explanation: Auto Scaling automatically adjusts capacity based on demand, making it ideal for variable traffic patterns. It ensures availability during spikes while reducing costs during low usage.

challenges.name: üí∞ Cost Optimization
challenges.description: Your AWS bill is higher than expected!
challenges.question: Which strategy BEST reduces EC2 costs for non-critical workloads?
options: Use only On-Demand instances for everything
Use Spot Instances for fault-tolerant, flexible workloads
Run instances 24/7 regardless of usage
Use the most expensive instance types
challenges.explanation: Spot Instances can save up to 90% compared to On-Demand pricing, making them ideal for fault-tolerant workloads like batch processing, data analysis, and testing environments.

challenges.name: üíµ Reserved Instances
challenges.question: When should you purchase Reserved Instances?
options: For unpredictable, sporadic workloads
For steady-state workloads with predictable usage
Never, they're always more expensive
Only for testing environments
challenges.explanation: Reserved Instances offer significant discounts (up to 75%) for committing to 1 or 3 years of usage, making them cost-effective for steady-state, predictable workloads.

challenges.name: üèóÔ∏è High Availability Design
challenges.question: How do you achieve high availability in AWS?
options: Deploy everything in a single Availability Zone
Distribute resources across multiple Availability Zones
Use only one EC2 instance for simplicity
Avoid using load balancers
challenges.explanation: High availability requires distributing resources across multiple Availability Zones. This protects against zone failures and ensures service continuity during outages.

challenges.name: üîÑ Load Balancer Selection
challenges.description: Choosing the right load balancer for your application!
challenges.question: When should you use an Application Load Balancer (ALB) vs Network Load Balancer (NLB)?
options: Always use NLB for better performance
Use ALB for HTTP/HTTPS traffic with advanced routing; NLB for TCP/UDP
They are identical, choose randomly
Never use load balancers
challenges.explanation: ALB operates at Layer 7 (application layer) and is best for HTTP/HTTPS with features like path-based routing. NLB operates at Layer 4 (transport layer) for TCP/UDP traffic requiring ultra-low latency.

challenges.name: üì¶ Container Orchestration
challenges.question: What is the primary benefit of using ECS or EKS?
options: It makes containers unnecessary
Automated deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications
It replaces the need for EC2
It only works for small applications
challenges.explanation: ECS (Elastic Container Service) and EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) automate container orchestration, handling deployment, scaling, load balancing, and service discovery for microservices.

challenges.name: üîß Terraform State Management
challenges.description: Managing Terraform state for team collaboration!
challenges.question: What is the BEST practice for storing Terraform state in a team environment?
options: Store state files in Git repository
Use remote backend (like S3) with state locking (DynamoDB)
Keep state files on your local machine
Delete state files after each apply
challenges.explanation: Remote state backend (S3) with state locking (DynamoDB) prevents conflicts, enables collaboration, and provides backup. Never store state in Git (contains sensitive data) or delete it.

challenges.name: üõ°Ô∏è DDoS Protection
challenges.description: Your infrastructure is under threat of DDoS attacks!
challenges.question: Which AWS service provides DDoS protection?
options: AWS WAF only
AWS Shield (Standard and Advanced)
Security Groups
CloudWatch
challenges.explanation: AWS Shield provides DDoS protection. Shield Standard is free and automatic. Shield Advanced offers enhanced protection and 24/7 DDoS response team support.

challenges.name: üìä Monitoring and Logging
challenges.description: Need better visibility into your infrastructure!
challenges.question: What is the difference between CloudWatch and CloudTrail?
options: They are identical services
CloudWatch monitors resources; CloudTrail logs API calls and user activity
CloudTrail only works with EC2
CloudWatch is only for billing
challenges.explanation: CloudWatch monitors performance metrics and sets alarms. CloudTrail logs all API calls for security auditing and compliance. Both are essential for different aspects of monitoring.

challenges.name: üîÑ Backup and Disaster Recovery
challenges.question: What is the difference between RTO and RPO in disaster recovery?
options: They mean the same thing
RTO = Recovery Time Objective (downtime); RPO = Recovery Point Objective (data loss)
RTO is for databases only
RPO doesn't matter in cloud environments
challenges.explanation: RTO defines maximum acceptable downtime. RPO defines maximum acceptable data loss. For example: RTO=4hrs means recovery within 4hrs; RPO=1hr means at most 1hr of data loss.

challenges.name: üîë SSH Key Management
challenges.description: Managing access to EC2 instances securely!
challenges.question: What is the BEST practice for managing SSH keys for EC2 instances?
options: Share the same key pair across all team members
Use unique key pairs per user and rotate them regularly
Store private keys in the Git repository for team access
Use password authentication instead of keys
challenges.explanation: Each user should have their own key pair for accountability. Regular rotation minimizes risk if keys are compromised. Never share keys or store private keys in version control.

challenges.name: üì° VPC Network Design
challenges.question: What is the purpose of using public and private subnets in a VPC?
options: There is no difference between public and private subnets
Public subnets for internet-facing resources; private subnets for backend services
Private subnets are cheaper than public subnets
Public subnets are only for static websites
challenges.explanation: Public subnets have routes to Internet Gateways for resources that need internet access (like load balancers). Private subnets isolate backend services (databases, app servers) without direct internet exposure.

challenges.name: ‚è±Ô∏è Lambda Cold Starts
challenges.description: Your Lambda functions are experiencing latency issues!
challenges.question: How can you minimize Lambda cold start times?
options: Use the largest memory allocation possible
Use Provisioned Concurrency for critical functions
Run Lambda functions continuously 24/7
Cold starts cannot be reduced
challenges.explanation: Provisioned Concurrency keeps functions initialized and ready to respond immediately. Other strategies include optimizing package size, using compiled languages, and keeping functions warm strategically.

challenges.name: üíæ Database Backup Strategy
challenges.description: Implementing a robust backup strategy for RDS!
challenges.question: What is the BEST backup strategy for production RDS databases?
options: Rely only on RDS automated backups (retention: 1 day)
Use automated backups with appropriate retention + manual snapshots before major changes
No backups needed - AWS handles everything
Only take backups when you remember to
challenges.explanation: Combine automated daily backups (7-35 day retention) with manual snapshots before major changes. Automated backups enable point-in-time recovery, while manual snapshots provide long-term recovery points.

challenges.name: üåç Multi-Region Deployment
challenges.question: Why would you deploy your application across multiple AWS regions?
options: To increase costs and complexity
For disaster recovery, lower latency for global users, and compliance requirements
AWS requires multi-region deployment
Single region is always better
challenges.explanation: Multi-region deployment provides disaster recovery (region failure protection), reduces latency for global users by serving from nearby regions, and meets data residency/compliance requirements.

challenges.name: üîç CloudWatch Alarms
challenges.description: Setting up effective monitoring and alerting!
challenges.question: What metrics should you monitor with CloudWatch alarms for EC2 instances?
options: Only CPU utilization
CPU, memory, disk I/O, network, and application-specific metrics
No monitoring needed if using Auto Scaling
Only monitor during business hours
challenges.explanation: Comprehensive monitoring includes CPU, memory (requires CloudWatch agent), disk I/O, network throughput, status checks, and custom application metrics. Multiple alarms provide early warning of issues.

challenges.name: üîê Secrets Management
challenges.question: How should you store database passwords and API keys in AWS?
options: Hardcode them in application code
Use AWS Secrets Manager or Parameter Store with encryption
Store them in environment variables in plain text
Keep them in a text file on S3
challenges.explanation: AWS Secrets Manager and Systems Manager Parameter Store provide encrypted storage, automatic rotation, and audit trails. Never hardcode secrets or store them unencrypted.

challenges.name: üìà Elastic Beanstalk vs ECS
challenges.question: When should you use Elastic Beanstalk instead of ECS?
options: Elastic Beanstalk is always better than ECS
For simple applications with minimal configuration; ECS for complex microservices
ECS is deprecated, always use Beanstalk
They are exactly the same service
challenges.explanation: Elastic Beanstalk abstracts infrastructure management for simple deployments. ECS provides more control and flexibility for containerized microservices architectures with complex requirements.

challenges.name: üóÇÔ∏è S3 Storage Classes
challenges.question: Which S3 storage class is BEST for infrequently accessed data with millisecond retrieval?
options: S3 Standard
S3 Standard-IA (Infrequent Access)
S3 Glacier Deep Archive
S3 One Zone-IA
challenges.explanation: S3 Standard-IA offers lower storage costs than Standard, with millisecond access times, making it ideal for infrequent access. Glacier is for archival (minutes to hours retrieval), and One Zone-IA sacrifices redundancy.

challenges.name: üîÑ API Gateway Throttling
challenges.description: Protecting your backend services from overload!
challenges.question: Why should you configure throttling on API Gateway?
options: To make the API slower for all users
To protect backend services from being overwhelmed and control costs
Throttling is not necessary for APIs
To increase AWS bills
challenges.explanation: Throttling prevents backend services from being overwhelmed by request spikes, protects against DDoS attacks, controls costs, and ensures fair usage across clients.

challenges.name: üéØ Target Groups
challenges.question: What is a target group in the context of AWS load balancers?
options: A marketing segmentation tool
A logical grouping of targets (EC2, Lambda, IP) that receive traffic from load balancer
A security group for targets
An IAM group for users
challenges.explanation: Target groups route requests to registered targets (EC2 instances, containers, Lambda functions, or IP addresses) based on configured health checks and routing rules.

challenges.name: üîí Encryption at Rest
challenges.question: Which AWS services support encryption at rest?
options: Only S3 supports encryption
S3, EBS, RDS, DynamoDB, and most AWS storage services
Encryption at rest is not available in AWS
Only enterprise accounts can use encryption
challenges.explanation: Most AWS storage services support encryption at rest using AWS KMS: S3, EBS volumes, RDS databases, DynamoDB tables, Redshift, and more. It's a best practice for sensitive data.

challenges.name: ‚ö° ElastiCache Use Cases
challenges.question: When should you use ElastiCache (Redis/Memcached)?
options: Only for session storage
For caching database queries, session storage, real-time analytics, and leaderboards
ElastiCache is only for gaming applications
Never, databases are always faster
challenges.explanation: ElastiCache accelerates applications by caching frequently accessed data, storing session information, powering real-time analytics, and maintaining leaderboards/counters with sub-millisecond latency.

challenges.name: üåê Route 53 Routing Policies
challenges.description: Configuring DNS routing for your application!
challenges.question: Which Route 53 routing policy routes traffic based on endpoint health?
options: Simple routing
Failover routing
Geolocation routing
Latency routing
challenges.explanation: Failover routing monitors endpoint health and automatically routes to healthy endpoints. It's essential for high availability, directing traffic to standby resources when primary fails.

challenges.name: üíº AWS Organizations
challenges.question: What is the primary benefit of using AWS Organizations?
options: It makes AWS more expensive
Centralized billing, policy management, and resource sharing across multiple accounts
It's only for companies with 1000+ employees
Organizations are required for all AWS accounts
challenges.explanation: AWS Organizations enables centralized billing (volume discounts), Service Control Policies (SCPs) for governance, resource sharing, and organizational structure for multiple accounts.

challenges.name: üîß Infrastructure as Code Benefits
challenges.description: Understanding the value of IaC tools like Terraform!
challenges.question: What is the PRIMARY benefit of using Infrastructure as Code?
options: It makes infrastructure more expensive
Consistent, repeatable, version-controlled infrastructure deployments
IaC is only for large enterprises
Manual deployment is always better
challenges.explanation: IaC treats infrastructure like software: version controlled, peer reviewed, tested, and repeatable. It eliminates manual errors, enables collaboration, and provides audit trails.

challenges.name: üé® Well-Architected Framework
challenges.question: What are the pillars of the AWS Well-Architected Framework?
options: Only Cost Optimization
Operational Excellence, Security, Reliability, Performance, Cost Optimization, Sustainability
There are no official pillars
Only Security and Performance
challenges.explanation: The six pillars provide best practices: Operational Excellence (run/monitor), Security (protect), Reliability (recover), Performance Efficiency (use resources), Cost Optimization (avoid waste), Sustainability (minimize environmental impact).

challenges.name: üîê IAM Roles vs Users
challenges.question: When should you use IAM roles instead of IAM users?
options: Never use roles, always use users
For applications, services, and temporary access; users for people
Roles and users are identical
Roles are only for administrators
challenges.explanation: Use IAM roles for applications (EC2, Lambda), cross-account access, and temporary credentials. Use IAM users for individual people. Roles provide temporary credentials without long-term access keys.

challenges.name: üìä Cost Allocation Tags
challenges.question: Why should you use cost allocation tags?
options: Tags have no impact on billing
To track costs by project, team, environment, and optimize spending
Tags are only for organization, not billing
Cost allocation tags increase your AWS bill
challenges.explanation: Cost allocation tags let you categorize and track AWS costs by project, department, environment, etc. This enables detailed cost reports and helps identify optimization opportunities.

challenges.name: üõ†Ô∏è Systems Manager Session Manager
challenges.description: Secure instance access without SSH keys!
challenges.question: What is the advantage of using Session Manager over SSH?
options: SSH is always more secure than Session Manager
No need for SSH keys, bastion hosts, or open inbound ports; full audit logging
Session Manager only works on Windows
SSH should always be used instead
challenges.explanation: Session Manager provides secure shell access through AWS console/CLI without SSH keys, bastion hosts, or inbound security group rules. All sessions are logged for compliance and auditing.

challenges.name: üåä Data Transfer Costs
challenges.description: Understanding and optimizing data transfer pricing!
challenges.question: Which data transfer scenario typically incurs the HIGHEST cost?
options: Data transfer within the same Availability Zone
Data transfer out to the internet
Data transfer between AWS services in the same region
All data transfer is free
challenges.explanation: Data transfer OUT to the internet is typically most expensive. Transfer within same AZ is free, between AZs in same region has minimal cost, and CloudFront can reduce egress costs.

challenges.name: üîÑ Blue/Green Deployments
challenges.question: What is the purpose of blue/green deployment?
options: To use blue and green colors in the UI
To enable zero-downtime deployments with instant rollback capability
It's a marketing strategy
Blue/green is only for testing
challenges.explanation: Blue/green deployment maintains two identical environments. Deploy to green (inactive), test it, then switch traffic from blue to green. Instant rollback by switching back if issues arise.

challenges.name: üìù CloudFormation vs Terraform
challenges.question: What is a key difference between CloudFormation and Terraform?
options: They are exactly the same
CloudFormation is AWS-only; Terraform supports multiple cloud providers
Terraform only works with AWS
CloudFormation is always better
challenges.explanation: CloudFormation is AWS-native and deeply integrated with AWS services. Terraform is cloud-agnostic, supporting AWS, Azure, GCP, and more, making it ideal for multi-cloud strategies.

challenges.name: üîí VPC Security Best Practices
challenges.question: What is the purpose of a NAT Gateway in a VPC?
options: To allow inbound internet traffic to private subnets
To allow private subnet resources to access internet while staying private
NAT Gateways are unnecessary
To replace security groups
challenges.explanation: NAT Gateway enables resources in private subnets to initiate outbound connections to the internet (for updates, API calls) while preventing inbound connections from the internet.

challenges.name: ‚öôÔ∏è EC2 Instance Types
challenges.description: Selecting the right instance type for your workload!
challenges.question: Which EC2 instance family is optimized for memory-intensive applications?
options: T-series (t3, t4g)
R-series (r5, r6)
C-series (c5, c6)
I-series (i3, i4)
challenges.explanation: R-series instances are memory-optimized for databases, caching, and real-time big data. C-series is compute-optimized, T-series is burstable, and I-series is storage-optimized.

challenges.name: üéØ Lambda Best Practices
challenges.question: What is a Lambda best practice for production?
options: Put all code in a single massive Lambda function
Keep functions small, single-purpose, and use environment variables for config
Never use environment variables
Always use maximum timeout (15 minutes)
challenges.explanation: Follow single responsibility principle, use environment variables for configuration, set appropriate timeouts/memory, handle errors gracefully, and use Lambda Layers for shared code.

challenges.name: üí≥ AWS Free Tier
challenges.question: Which statement about AWS Free Tier is TRUE?
options: Everything in AWS is always free
Some services offer always-free tier, 12-month free tier, or trial periods
Free Tier is only for students
You must pay after 1 month regardless of usage
challenges.explanation: AWS Free Tier has three types: Always Free (Lambda 1M requests/month), 12 Months Free (750hrs t2.micro EC2), and Trials (limited time). Exceeding limits incurs charges.

challenges.name: üîê KMS Key Management
challenges.question: What is AWS KMS (Key Management Service) used for?
options: Managing EC2 instance keys only
Creating and controlling encryption keys for AWS services and applications
KMS is only for CloudTrail
Managing user passwords
challenges.explanation: KMS creates, manages, and controls cryptographic keys used across AWS services and your applications. It provides centralized key management with audit trails via CloudTrail.

challenges.name: üöÄ Global Accelerator
challenges.question: How does AWS Global Accelerator improve application performance?
options: It makes your code run faster
Uses AWS global network to route traffic to optimal endpoints, reducing latency
It only works for static websites
Global Accelerator increases costs without benefits
challenges.explanation: Global Accelerator uses AWS's global network infrastructure and edge locations to route user traffic to the optimal regional endpoint, reducing internet latency and improving availability.

challenges.name: üì¶ EBS Volume Types
challenges.description: Choosing the right storage for EC2!
challenges.question: Which EBS volume type provides the highest IOPS performance?
options: gp2 (General Purpose SSD)
io2 Block Express (Provisioned IOPS SSD)
st1 (Throughput Optimized HDD)
sc1 (Cold HDD)
challenges.explanation: io2 Block Express provides up to 256,000 IOPS for critical, I/O-intensive workloads. gp3/gp2 are general purpose, st1/sc1 are HDD for throughput-oriented or cold data.

challenges.name: üîç AWS Config
challenges.question: What does AWS Config do?
options: Configures AWS resources automatically
Tracks resource configurations, changes, and compliance with rules over time
Replaces CloudFormation
Only monitors costs
challenges.explanation: AWS Config continuously monitors and records AWS resource configurations, evaluates them against desired configurations (Config Rules), and maintains a history of changes for compliance auditing.

challenges.name: üé™ Service Quotas
challenges.question: What should you do if you hit an AWS service quota/limit?
options: Nothing, limits cannot be changed
Request a quota increase through Service Quotas console or AWS Support
Create a new AWS account
AWS will automatically increase limits
challenges.explanation: Most AWS service quotas are soft limits that can be increased via Service Quotas console or support ticket. Plan ahead and request increases before hitting limits in production.

challenges.name: üîÑ RDS Multi-AZ
challenges.question: What is the purpose of RDS Multi-AZ deployment?
options: To improve read performance
To provide automatic failover for high availability during outages
To reduce costs
Multi-AZ is only for backups
challenges.explanation: Multi-AZ maintains a synchronous standby replica in another AZ. During failures, RDS automatically fails over to the standby (typically 60-120 seconds), providing high availability without data loss.

challenges.name: üí° Savings Plans
challenges.question: What is the difference between Savings Plans and Reserved Instances?
options: They are identical
Savings Plans offer flexibility across instance families/regions; RIs are more specific
Savings Plans are always more expensive
Reserved Instances are deprecated
challenges.explanation: Savings Plans provide flexibility to change instance families, sizes, OS, or regions while maintaining savings. RIs offer deeper discounts but less flexibility. Both require 1 or 3-year commitment.
